CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 11, 1953, pg. 12, reads: "Mrs. Franklin Walker." Accompanying article reads: "A Garden Wedding - Sunday, June 28, was the day chosen by Ethel Roberta Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Stevens of Pittsburgh, to become the wife of Franklin Walker Jr., son of the Franklin Walkers Sr., also of Pittsburgh.  Her parents' garden was the setting for the rites, which were read by Elder Harry Dobbins of Camden, N. J.  The bride wore a white embroidered organdy dress.  A crown of seed pearls held her fingertip-length veil in place.  She carried an orchid with a spray of carnations on a white Bible.  Hortense Moran, teacher and resident of Washington, D. C., was maid of honor.  Ruth Mosby, dean of women at Oakwood College, was a bridesmaid.  The groom's brother-in-law, Ronald Pittsman, was his best man.  The bride was given in marriage by her father.  Out-of-town guests attending were Mr. and Mrs. Robert Smith, Mrs. Magnolia and Darrell Kallins, Mrs. Lulie Robinson, Eddie Dudley, Isaac Richardson, from Newark N. J.; Kathyn Sedgewick, Baltimore, Md.; Mrs. Coes, Mr. and Mrs. Middletown, Ohio,;  Carol Dickerson of Camden, N. J.; Fermandy Washington, Long Island; Miriam Gresham, Pine Forge Institute; Jessie and Edward Ford, Peter McClary and Jonathan Walker, Pine Forge Institute.  Before her marriage, the bride was employed as a teacher and accountant at the Pine Forge Institute.  She is a graduate of Columbia University.  The groom is employed at the Officers Reservation, Lewisburg, Pa., where the couple will make their home."
TitMainTitle: Wedding guests throwing rice at bride Ethel Roberta Smith Walker and Franklin Walker Jr., on lawn of home of Ernest Stevens, 914 Adelaide Street, Hill District
